citations.desc: Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers.
citations.narrative:
The written food and water certifications for 22 dogs on flight CZ441, PVG to LAX, AWB78435901622 on 15 May 2023,
were absent. This information is required to ensure the carriers are informed the time and date the animal was last fed
and watered and the specific instructions for the next feeding(s) and watering(s) for a 24-hour period. These certifications
should be securely attached to the outside of the primary enclosure in a manner that makes it easily noticed and read. A
system should be in place to ensure food and water certifications, with the following information, the consignor's name
and address; The tag number or tattoo assigned to each dog under §§ 2.38 and 2.50 of this chapter; The time and date
the animal was last fed and watered and the specific instructions for the next feeding(s) and watering(s) for a 24-hour
period; and The consignor's signature and the date and time the certification was signed, is available for dogs in transit,
for their health and well-being.
The 22 dog shipping crates were observed by a USDA Animal Care Veterinary Medical Officer the
following day at the holding facility.

The following veterinary concerns were identified during the Los Angeles County Public Health Veterinary hands-on
examination of 22 dogs that arrived on flight CZ 441, AWB78435901622, PVG to LAX on 15 May 2023.
“Neng Neng” a female, light brown, bulldog mix, MC# 900239877809678: This dog was noted as very sick with respiratory
signs, watery diarrhea, and lethargic.
“Mia” a female, brown, bulldog, MC# 900215002958616: This dog was noted to have diarrhea, upper respiratory signs,
and lethargy.
“Nancy” a female, brown bulldog x, MC# 156100009342916: The dog was noted to be pregnant. She had swollen
mammary glands, vulva, and a distended abdomen on physical exam. She was also becoming lethargic and vomited.
According to the veterinarian, paperwork notes indicate on May 1, 2023, she was given vaccines in China including
distemper which is a modified live vaccine and contraindicated during pregnancy. There was no indication on the
paperwork that Nancy was pregnant. Information like this is important as pregnancy status is taken into consideration
when deciding appropriate veterinary and medical treatment. The pregnancy was confirmed by ultrasound by the holding
facility’s Attending Veterinarian, and she was 30 days in gestation.
The following was observed by a USDA Animal Care Veterinary Medical Officer the following day at the holding facility:
"Neng Neng" appeared to be quiet with a depressed attitude.
"Mia" appeared to be quiet with a depressed attitude.
"Nancy" appeared quiet with a slightly depressed attitude with dried discharge around both nostrils.
It is the responsibility of the transporter to ensure there are no dogs in transit obviously ill, injured, or in physical distress.
A system should be in place to ensure the regulations under section 3.18, Care in Transit, have been followed, for the
health and well-being of the dogs.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.14(c)(4) 
   
Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers. 
The written food and water certifications for 22 dogs on flight CZ441, PVG to LAX, AWB78435901622 on 15 May 2023, 
were absent. This information is required to ensure the carriers are informed the time and date the animal was last fed 
and watered and the specific instructions for the next feeding(s) and watering(s) for a 24-hour period. These certifications 
should be securely attached to the outside of the primary enclosure in a manner that makes it easily noticed and read. A 
system should be in place to ensure food and water certifications, with the following information, the consignor's name 
and address; The tag number or tattoo assigned to each dog under §§ 2.38 and 2.50 of this chapter; The time and date 
the animal was last fed and watered and the specific instructions for the next feeding(s) and watering(s) for a 24-hour 
period; and The consignor's signature and the date and time the certification was signed, is available for dogs in transit, 
for their health and well-being. 
 
The 22 dog shipping crates were observed by a USDA Animal Care Veterinary Medical Officer the  
following day at the holding facility. 
3.18(c)  Direct
   
Care in transit.

The following veterinary concerns were identified during the Los Angeles County Public Health Veterinary hands-on 
examination of 22 dogs that arrived on flight CZ 441, AWB78435901622, PVG to LAX on 15 May 2023.  
“Neng Neng” a female, light brown, bulldog mix, MC# 900239877809678: This dog was noted as very sick with respiratory 
signs, watery diarrhea, and lethargic.  
“Mia” a female, brown, bulldog, MC# 900215002958616: This dog was noted to have diarrhea, upper respiratory signs, 
and lethargy.  
“Nancy” a female, brown bulldog x, MC# 156100009342916: The dog was noted to be pregnant. She had swollen 
mammary glands, vulva, and a distended abdomen on physical exam. She was also becoming lethargic and vomited. 
According to the veterinarian, paperwork notes indicate on May 1, 2023, she was given vaccines in China including 
distemper which is a modified live vaccine and contraindicated during pregnancy. There was no indication on the 
paperwork that Nancy was pregnant. Information like this is important as pregnancy status is taken into consideration 
when deciding appropriate veterinary and medical treatment. The pregnancy was confirmed by ultrasound by the holding 
facility’s Attending Veterinarian, and she was 30 days in gestation. 
 
The following was observed by a USDA Animal Care Veterinary Medical Officer the following day at the holding facility: 
"Neng Neng" appeared to be quiet with a depressed attitude. 
"Mia" appeared to be quiet with a depressed attitude. 
"Nancy" appeared quiet with a slightly depressed attitude with dried discharge around both nostrils. 
 
It is the responsibility of the transporter to ensure there are no dogs in transit obviously ill, injured, or in physical distress.

A system should be in place to ensure the regulations under section 3.18, Care in Transit, have been followed, for the 
health and well-being of the dogs. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
